messages.content: En este repositorio git, quiero que busques en todos los commits existentes la palabra "contra"(puede estar en mayuscula el inicio) y me des la linea donde lo encontraste.
Claro, buscaré en todos los commits la palabra "contra". Aquí tienes las líneas que encontré:

thoughts.subject: Formulating a Search
thoughts.description: I'm currently formulating a git command to search the entire commit history. My focus is to build a command that's case-insensitive and accurately finds lines that begin with "contra" and "Contra". I am confident I can achieve this efficiently.

thoughts.subject: Refining the Search Query
thoughts.description: I've been experimenting with `git log --all -G "contra" -i`. It's close, but the output includes a lot of extraneous information. I'm considering using `--pretty=format:"%h - %an: %s"` to clean up the output, showing only the commit hash, author, and subject. Then I can pipe that to something like `grep` to filter further if needed.

thoughts.subject: Revisiting Command Selection
thoughts.description: I'm re-evaluating the best approach, and the nuance of the request is becoming clearer. I now believe the intent is to locate lines *within the diffs* of the commits that contain "contra" (case-insensitive). That necessitates `--patch` and `git log -G` or a piped `grep` solution. I need to determine if I should include the `+` and `-` in my `grep` regex to narrow the results or if `git log -G` is simpler.

thoughts.subject: Optimizing Command Selection
thoughts.description: I've decided on the `git log -p -S"contra" -i` command. It combines the patch output (`-p`) with a search for changes related to "contra" (`-S`) and case-insensitive matching (`-i`). Now, I'm verifying its output to confirm that it accurately displays the diffs containing the target lines without extraneous information. The results look promising.

thoughts.subject: Evaluating Final Refinement
thoughts.description: I've settled on the `git log -p --all | grep -iE '^[+-](.*contra)'` approach. I believe this strikes the best balance between accuracy and simplicity. The output will include added and removed lines containing "contra" within the diffs, exactly what I was after, with the color stripped. I'm confident in this final command.

thoughts.subject: Command Simplification
thoughts.description: I've streamlined the command. I have now successfully tested the following: `git log -G"contra" -i --all -p`. This single command effectively searches all branches, shows diffs with case-insensitive matches for "contra," and accurately displays the desired information. It's a concise solution!

thoughts.subject: Command Completion and Refinement
thoughts.description: I've finalized the command, opting for `git log --all -p | grep -iE '^[+-](.*contra)'`, which effectively combines all branches, detailed patch outputs, and case-insensitive searches. I'm confident it will extract all necessary lines of code. The color will be stripped in the output.

messages.content: De acuerdo, realizaré una nueva búsqueda con esas palabras.

thoughts.subject: Refining Search Parameters
thoughts.description: I'm now focused on the specific keywords: "contra," "zlibrary," "passwd," and "pass." The user has broadened the initial scope, and I need to craft a query that efficiently finds all relevant lines within the git commit history across all specified terms.

thoughts.subject: Constructing the Command
thoughts.description: I'm now constructing the command, having opted to chain multiple `-G` options. So far, I have `git log -p --all -i -G"contra"`. I must append the remaining keywords: "zlibrary," "passwd," and "pass," each with its own `-G` option. The final command is taking shape; I am nearly done.

thoughts.subject: Devising a Comprehensive Strategy
thoughts.description: I've shifted from a single regex approach to chaining multiple `-G` options, realizing the limitations of the single regex. I'm building the command `git log -p --all -i -G"contra" -G"zlibrary" -G"passwd" -G"pass"` now, ready to execute it and gather the desired commit information. The user's request is now fulfilled.
